elements.content: Imines are ubiquitous intermediates in organic synthesis, and the metal–mediated imination of alcohols is one of the most direct and simple methods for their synthesis. However, reported protocols lack compatibility with many other functional groups since basic supports/media, pure oxygen atmospheres, and/or released hydrogen gas are required during reaction. Here we show that, in contrast to previous metal-catalyzed methods, hexa-aqueous Ru­(III) catalyzes the imination of primary alcohols with very wide functional group tolerance, at slightly acid pH and under low oxygen atmospheres. The inorganic metal complex can be supported and stabilized, integrally, within either faujasite-type zeolites (Y and X) or a metal organic framework (MOF), to give a reusable heterogeneous catalyst which provides an industrially viable process well below the flammability limit of alcohols and amines.
elements.clean_text: Imines are ubiquitous intermediates in organic synthesis, and the metal-mediated imination of alcohols is one of the most direct and simple methods for their synthesis. However, reported protocols lack compatibility with many other functional groups since basic supports/media, pure oxygen atmospheres, and/or released hydrogen gas are required during reaction. Here we show that, in contrast to previous metal-catalyzed methods, hexa-aqueous Ru(III) catalyzes the imination of primary alcohols with very wide functional group tolerance, at slightly acid pH and under low oxygen atmospheres. The inorganic metal complex can be supported and stabilized, integrally, within either faujasite-type zeolites (Y and X) or a metal organic framework (MOF), to give a reusable heterogeneous catalyst which provides an industrially viable process well below the flammability limit of alcohols and amines.

elements.content: Ru is one of the most used and versatile metal catalysts for the dehydrogenation of alcohols, however, it is barely used for the dehydrogenating imination reaction. On one hand, dehydrogenating catalytic Ru­(II) complexes (i.e., pincer-type organoRu­(II) complexes) produce H2 during the reaction, which reduces the imine, and on the other hand, high-valent Ru­(IV) and (VI) compounds (i.e., tetrapropylammonium perruthenate, TPAP, and RuO2) and Ru­(II) catalysts (i.e., Ru­(PPh)3Cl2 and Ru­(p-cymene)­Cl2) use sacrificial oxidants to quench the Ru-hydrides, which are not compatible with many functional groups.
elements.clean_text: Ru is one of the most used and versatile metal catalysts for the dehydrogenation of alcohols, however, it is barely used for the dehydrogenating imination reaction. On one hand, dehydrogenating catalytic Ru(II) complexes (i.e., pincer-type organoRu(II) complexes) produce H2 during the reaction, which reduces the imine, and on the other hand, high-valent Ru(IV) and (VI) compounds (i.e., tetrapropylammonium perruthenate, TPAP, and RuO2) and Ru(II) catalysts (i.e., Ru(PPh)3Cl2 and Ru(p-cymene)Cl2) use sacrificial oxidants to quench the Ru-hydrides, which are not compatible with many functional groups.

elements.content: Indeed, it is difficult to find functional group tolerant protocols for the imination of alcohols for any metal catalyst. The metal catalyst faces the challenge of avoiding hydrogen borrowing mechanisms by rapidly quenching or releasing the so-formed hydrides and, at the same time, shifting the equilibrium toward the imine product. These combined redox/acid–base requirements are even more hampered for aldimines, key intermediates for the synthesis of a plethora of commercially-relevant nitrogen-containing organic molecules, since the dehydrogenation of primary alcohols requires strong basic conditions and promotes decarbonylation reactions. Should any powerful Ru catalyst for the dehydrogenation of alcohols operate in nonbasic media and engage amines without giving hydrogen atoms back or using strong oxidizing conditions, an inherently very active and selective metal catalyst for the direct imination of alcohols will arise.
elements.clean_text: Indeed, it is difficult to find functional group tolerant protocols for the imination of alcohols for any metal catalyst.  The metal catalyst faces the challenge of avoiding hydrogen borrowing mechanisms by rapidly quenching or releasing the so-formed hydrides and, at the same time, shifting the equilibrium toward the imine product. These combined redox/acid-base requirements are even more hampered for aldimines, key intermediates for the synthesis of a plethora of commercially-relevant nitrogen-containing organic molecules, since the dehydrogenation of primary alcohols requires strong basic conditions and promotes decarbonylation reactions. Should any powerful Ru catalyst for the dehydrogenation of alcohols operate in nonbasic media and engage amines without giving hydrogen atoms back or using strong oxidizing conditions, an inherently very active and selective metal catalyst for the direct imination of alcohols will arise.

elements.content: (entries 1–14) shows the imination of 4-vinylbenzyl alcohol (1) and 3,4-dimethylaniline (2) catalyzed by 5 mol % of 15 representative Ru catalysts, in toluene at 90 °C, and with 2 equiv of O2, which corresponds to the amount of air in the vial. Notice that these atmospheric conditions are extremely mild and fulfill flammability limitations in industry for organic compounds. The first results in confirm the difficulties mentioned above, and Ru­(II) or (III), salts and complexes (entries 1–5), pincer-type complexes (entries 7–10), and supported Ru nanoparticles (entries 11–12) do not give imine 3 (complex A Milstein’s aceptorless dehydrogenating catalyst gives 35% of the amine product, entry 6), while high-valent Ru compounds (entries 13–14) act as stoichiometric rather than catalytic agents, to yield the amount of imine 3 corresponding to reducible Ru.

Notice that these atmospheric conditions are extremely mild and fulfill flammability limitations in industry for organic compounds. The first results in  confirm the difficulties mentioned above, and Ru(II) or (III), salts and complexes (entries 1-5), pincer-type complexes (entries 7-10), and supported Ru nanoparticles (entries 11-12) do not give imine 3 (complex A Milstein's aceptorless dehydrogenating catalyst gives 35% of the amine product, entry 6), while high-valent Ru compounds (entries 13-14) act as stoichiometric rather than catalytic agents, to yield the amount of imine 3 corresponding to reducible Ru.

elements.content:
Results for the Imination of 4-Vinylbenzyl Alcohol (<bold>1</bold>) and 3,4-Dimethylaniline (<bold>2</bold>) with Ru Catalysts Entry Ru catalyst Yield of 3 (%) 1 RuCl3 0 2 Ru(acac)3 0 3 RuCl2(PPh)3 0 4 RuCl2(NH3)6 0 5 RuCl2(p-cymene) 0 6 Complex A 0 7 Complex B 0 8 Complex C 5 9 Complex D 0 10 Complex E 0 11 Ru (5 wt %)–C 0 12 Ru–Al2O3 0 13 TPAP 36 14 RuO2 14 15 Ru[(H2O)6]·3BF4 21 (18) 16 Ru(H2O)6–Al2O3 (0.1 wt % Ru) 27 17 Ru(H2O)6–SiO2 (0.1 wt % Ru) 26 18 Ru(H2O)6–TiO2 (0.1 wt % Ru) 23 19 Ru(H2O)6–MgO (0.1 wt % Ru) 20 20 Ru[(H2O)6]3+–NaY (1 wt % Ru) 73 (65) 21 [RuH2O)6]3+–MOF (∼3 wt % Ru) 97 (90) 22 Ru(OH)3– Al2O3 (1 wt % Ru) 7

2 equiv of O2 corresponds to the air in the vial. GC yields. Between parentheses, isolated yields.

Hydrogenated imine as only product found.

63% isolated yield in 2 g-scale; 58% after 5 uses. A 3 wt % sample gives 56% isolated yield.

Bare zeolites and MOF do not give any product. TBAP = Tetrapropylammonium perruthenate.

In contrast, [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ (entry 15) shows truly catalytic activity and achieves 21% of imine 3. This Ru species, prepared in HBF4 solutions in the 60s and later supported in faujasite-type zeolites by simple cation exchange, has rarely been reported for catalysis, despite its simplicity. The combination of acidity, accessibility, and water-compatibility in a same Ru site seems favorable for the imination of alcohols. Unfortunately, monitoring the homogeneous reaction by in-situ ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy combined with kinetic experiments (Figure S1), with nonchromophoric reagents, showed the rapid degradation and the loss of catalytic activity of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ in toluene solution.
elements.clean_text: In contrast, [Ru(H2O)6]3+ (entry 15) shows truly catalytic activity and achieves 21% of imine 3. This Ru species, prepared in HBF4 solutions in the 60s and later supported in faujasite-type zeolites by simple cation exchange, has rarely been reported for catalysis, despite its simplicity. The combination of acidity, accessibility, and water-compatibility in a same Ru site seems favorable for the imination of alcohols. Unfortunately, monitoring the homogeneous reaction by in-situ ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectroscopy combined with kinetic experiments (Figure S1), with nonchromophoric reagents, showed the rapid degradation and the loss of catalytic activity of [Ru(H2O)6]3+ in toluene solution.

elements.content: A plausible way to overcome such a catalyst degradation in solution is to support the Ru active species onto a solid. However, this degradation is not avoided when supporting [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ on different amorphous inorganic oxides such as alumina, silica, titania and magnesia (entries 16–19), since the progressive loss of the fragile hexa–aqueous Ru­(III) cation still occurs.
elements.clean_text: A plausible way to overcome such a catalyst degradation in solution is to support the Ru active species onto a solid. However, this degradation is not avoided when supporting [Ru(H2O)6]3+ on different amorphous inorganic oxides such as alumina, silica, titania and magnesia (entries 16-19), since the progressive loss of the fragile hexa-aqueous Ru(III) cation still occurs.

elements.content: [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ depletion may come from the loss of ionic interaction in the organic medium between the soft Ru­(III) cation and the BF4 –/inorganic oxide counterbalancing anion, and, perhaps, a confining anionic solid with a delocalized charge and an intimate interaction with [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ may preserve its integrity and catalytic activity for longer. Indeed, Ru­[(H2O)6]3+–NaY (1 wt % Ru in the zeolite, entry 20) gives a 65% of isolated imine 3, 63% in 2 g-scale, and the solid is recyclable for at least 5 times without significant depletion in catalytic activity (58%). Hot–filtration experiments, at 20% conversion, show no catalytic activity after solid catalyst filtration, and ICP analysis confirms that the Ru loading remains constant on NaY after use. A NaY sample exchanged with 3 wt % instead of 1 wt % Ru (see footnote in ) works similarly, thus saving catalytic solid material. Diffuse reflectance (DR) UV–vis and infrared (IR) spectroscopy, together with Ru3p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–NaY treated with air in the XPS chamber at 100 °C, confirms the stability of the Ru­(III) site (Figure S2 and S3). These results strongly support the heterogeneous character of the catalysis.
elements.clean_text: [Ru(H2O)6]3+ depletion may come from the loss of ionic interaction in the organic medium between the soft Ru(III) cation and the BF4 -/inorganic oxide counterbalancing anion, and, perhaps, a confining anionic solid with a delocalized charge and an intimate interaction with [Ru(H2O)6]3+ may preserve its integrity and catalytic activity for longer. Indeed, Ru[(H2O)6]3+-NaY (1 wt % Ru in the zeolite, entry 20) gives a 65% of isolated imine 3, 63% in 2 g-scale, and the solid is recyclable for at least 5 times without significant depletion in catalytic activity (58%). Hot-filtration experiments, at 20% conversion, show no catalytic activity after solid catalyst filtration, and ICP analysis confirms that the Ru loading remains constant on NaY after use. A NaY sample exchanged with 3 wt % instead of 1 wt % Ru (see footnote in ) works similarly, thus saving catalytic solid material. Diffuse reflectance (DR) UV-vis and infrared (IR) spectroscopy, together with Ru3p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-NaY treated with air in the XPS chamber at 100 °C, confirms the stability of the Ru(III) site (Figure S2 and S3). These results strongly support the heterogeneous character of the catalysis.

elements.content: Hydrophobic solvents (hexane, α,α,α-trifluorotoluene and toluene) work better than polar solvents (Table S1), plausibly by enhancing zeolite–Ru­[(H2O)6]3+ ionic interaction. In order to assess that this zeolite–Ru­[(H2O)6]3+ interaction is crucial for the catalysis, faujasite electronics was varied by cation exchange, from electron-poor (thus highly acid, HY) to electron-rich (thus highly basic, CsX). DR UV–vis and IR spectra of the zeolites show the expected peaks for [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ and the absence of direct oxo–Ru bonds with the zeolite walls (Figure S2 and S5), which supports the integrity of the hexa–aqueous complex. The catalytic activity of the different [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–zeolite catalysts changes with the electronics, peaking for NaY and KY (Figure S4). The fact that the quasi neutral faujasite KY confers the better catalytic activity to the extraframework Ru­(III) site discards the participation of zeolite Brönsted sites during the imination reaction and strongly supports [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ as the intrinsic catalyst, stabilized in the zeolite. Following this hypothesis, it seemed highly promising to prepare new active solid catalysts by supporting [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ in other delocalized anionic solids, such as MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Hydrophobic solvents (hexane, α,α,α-trifluorotoluene and toluene) work better than polar solvents (Table S1), plausibly by enhancing zeolite-Ru[(H2O)6]3+ ionic interaction. In order to assess that this zeolite-Ru[(H2O)6]3+ interaction is crucial for the catalysis, faujasite electronics was varied by cation exchange, from electron-poor (thus highly acid, HY) to electron-rich (thus highly basic, CsX). DR UV-vis and IR spectra of the zeolites show the expected peaks for [Ru(H2O)6]3+ and the absence of direct oxo-Ru bonds with the zeolite walls (Figure S2 and S5), which supports the integrity of the hexa-aqueous complex. The catalytic activity of the different [Ru(H2O)6]3+-zeolite catalysts changes with the electronics, peaking for NaY and KY (Figure S4). The fact that the quasi neutral faujasite KY confers the better catalytic activity to the extraframework Ru(III) site discards the participation of zeolite Brönsted sites during the imination reaction and strongly supports [Ru(H2O)6]3+ as the intrinsic catalyst, stabilized in the zeolite. Following this hypothesis, it seemed highly promising to prepare new active solid catalysts by supporting [Ru(H2O)6]3+ in other delocalized anionic solids, such as MOFs.

elements.content: MOFs are porous crystalline materials showing a large variety of interesting propertiesmost of which arise from their porous character and amazing host–guest chemistryand find application in many different important fields. In particular, MOFs have already shown excellent results in supporting and stabilizing small metal clusters or metal complexes within their channels, showing high catalytic activity. In this context, we thus selected a highly robust anionic MOF of formula Ni2 II{NiII 4[CuII 2(Me3mpba)2]3}·54H2O, capable of exchanging the Ni2+ cations hosted within its pores by [Ru­(H2O)6]3+, in a similar procedure to cation exchange in zeolites. The postsynthetic single crystal to single crystal (SC to SC) process was monitored through SEM–EDX and ICP–AES (Table S2), whereas the Ru oxidation state and oxygen atom electronics were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Figures S6–S7). shows the single crystal X-ray crystallography (SC–XRC) results for the new MOF, with formula [ R u I I I ( H 2 O ) 6 ] 0.83 [ R u I I I 2 ( μ‐ H 2 O ) ( H 2 O ) 10 ] 0.25 { N i I I 4 [ C u I I 2 ( M e 3 m p b a ) 2 ] 3 } · 61 H 2 O ( [ R u ( H 2 O ) 6 ] 3 + −M O F )
elements.clean_text: MOFs are porous crystalline materials showing a large variety of interesting propertiesmost of which arise from their porous character and amazing host-guest chemistryand find application in many different important fields. In particular, MOFs have already shown excellent results in supporting and stabilizing small metal clusters or metal complexes within their channels, showing high catalytic activity. In this context, we thus selected a highly robust anionic MOF of formula Ni2 II{NiII 4[CuII 2(Me3mpba)2]3}⋅54H2O, capable of exchanging the Ni2+ cations hosted within its pores by [Ru(H2O)6]3+, in a similar procedure to cation exchange in zeolites. The postsynthetic single crystal to single crystal (SC to SC) process was monitored through SEM-EDX and ICP-AES (Table S2), whereas the Ru oxidation state and oxygen atom electronics were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Figures S6-S7).  shows the single crystal X-ray crystallography (SC-XRC) results for the new MOF, with formula       [ R   u   I I I     (   H   2   O )   6   ]   0.83     [ R     u   I I I     2    ( μ-   H   2   O )    (   H   2   O )   10   ]   0.25     { N     i   I I     4      [ C     u   I I     2     ( M   e   3   m p b a )   2   ]   3   }  ⋅  61   H   2   O   (   [ R u   (   H   2   O )   6   ]   3 +   -M O F )

elements.content: Views of the porous crystal structures, determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF in the ab (a) and bc (b) planes, respectively. (c) Perspective view of one single channel of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF along the c (left) axis. (d) Perspective view of a fragment of a single channel emphasizing the hydrogen bonds interactions. Cu­(II) and Ni­(II) cations from the coordination network are represented by cyan and blue polyhedra, respectively, whereas the ligands are depicted as gray sticks. Ru­(III) cations and water molecules hosted in the channels are represented by gold and red spheres with surface, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  Views of the porous crystal structures, determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF in the ab (a) and bc (b) planes, respectively. (c) Perspective view of one single channel of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF along the c (left) axis. (d) Perspective view of a fragment of a single channel emphasizing the hydrogen bonds interactions. Cu(II) and Ni(II) cations from the coordination network are represented by cyan and blue polyhedra, respectively, whereas the ligands are depicted as gray sticks. Ru(III) cations and water molecules hosted in the channels are represented by gold and red spheres with surface, respectively.

elements.content: a shows the [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ and [RuIII 2(μ-H2O)­(H2O)10]6+ units, respectively hosted in the two types of channels present in the anionic framework: the larger octagonal ones much more accessible for catalysis (vide infra) and the small square hindered channels. Both the hexa-aqua Ru­(III) monomers, located in octagonal pores, and [RuIII 2(μ-H2O)­(H2O)10]6+ dimers exhibit Ru–OH2 bond distances [1.97(1) to 2.37(3) Å], very similar to the only report found in the literature. This lack of reports on crystallographically defined [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ monomers further supports an intrinsic stabilizing effect of MOF’s confined space. The larger octagonal hydrophilic channels of the MOF contain a much larger accessible void space (size of ca. 2.2 nm), which contrasts with the very small amount of room available in the small square channels, almost fully occupied by the [RuIII 2(μ-H2O)­(H2O)10]6+ dimers (c and d). This point suggests that the [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ monomers located in the larger channels are potential catalytic species. Apart from electrostatic interactions between Ru3+ units and the anionic framework, all [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ cations located in both types of channels are hydrogen-bondedinvolving the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the framework and water molecules constituting the coordination environment of the Ru3+ ions [Owaters···Ooxamate 2.827(3) and 2.923(3) Å] to the anionic framework, which further fixes and stabilizes them within the pores (dashed lines in c, d and S8–S10). These results definitely underline how the interplay between hydrophilic channels and the consequent vastly solvated confined nanospacein which water molecules are noninnocent participantsis at the origin of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ moieties stabilizations and unambiguously confirms the integrity of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ within the porous solid.
elements.clean_text: a shows the [Ru(H2O)6]3+ and [RuIII 2(μ-H2O)(H2O)10]6+ units, respectively hosted in the two types of channels present in the anionic framework: the larger octagonal ones much more accessible for catalysis (vide infra) and the small square hindered channels. Both the hexa-aqua Ru(III) monomers, located in octagonal pores, and [RuIII 2(μ-H2O)(H2O)10]6+ dimers exhibit Ru-OH2 bond distances [1.97(1) to 2.37(3) Å], very similar to the only report found in the literature. This lack of reports on crystallographically defined [Ru(H2O)6]3+ monomers further supports an intrinsic stabilizing effect of MOF's confined space. The larger octagonal hydrophilic channels of the MOF contain a much larger accessible void space (size of ca. 2.2 nm), which contrasts with the very small amount of room available in the small square channels, almost fully occupied by the [RuIII 2(μ-H2O)(H2O)10]6+ dimers (c and d). This point suggests that the [Ru(H2O)6]3+ monomers located in the larger channels are potential catalytic species. Apart from electrostatic interactions between Ru3+ units and the anionic framework, all [Ru(H2O)6]3+ cations located in both types of channels are hydrogen-bondedinvolving the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the framework and water molecules constituting the coordination environment of the Ru3+ ions [Owaters⋅⋅⋅Ooxamate 2.827(3) and 2.923(3) Å] to the anionic framework, which further fixes and stabilizes them within the pores (dashed lines in c, d and S8-S10). These results definitely underline how the interplay between hydrophilic channels and the consequent vastly solvated confined nanospacein which water molecules are noninnocent participantsis at the origin of [Ru(H2O)6]3+ moieties stabilizations and unambiguously confirms the integrity of [Ru(H2O)6]3+ within the porous solid.

elements.content: The experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of a polycrystalline sample of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF are identical to the theoretical one (Figure S11), which confirms the purity of the bulk. Moreover, the chemical nature was further determined by elemental analysis (Supporting Information) and the water content was established by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure S12). There is a continuous loss of mass before 150 °C; however, this corresponds to physisorbed water and organic solvent traces and not to the aqueous complex, that decomposes at much higher temperature. Finally, the porosity of the MOF after the PS cation exchanged was confirmed by measuring the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K (Figure S13).
elements.clean_text: The experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of a polycrystalline sample of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF are identical to the theoretical one (Figure S11), which confirms the purity of the bulk. Moreover, the chemical nature was further determined by elemental analysis (Supporting Information) and the water content was established by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure S12). There is a continuous loss of mass before 150 °C; however, this corresponds to physisorbed water and organic solvent traces and not to the aqueous complex, that decomposes at much higher temperature. Finally, the porosity of the MOF after the PS cation exchanged was confirmed by measuring the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K (Figure S13).

elements.content: The [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF catalyst gives 90% isolated yield of imine 3 (entry 21 in ), the highest among all Ru catalysts tested. Hot-filtration experiments and ICP analysis show that Ru remains on the MOF after reaction, and XPS confirms the stability of the Ru catalyst within the MOF (Figures S6–S7). Kinetic experiments show that the initial turnover frequencies TOF0 for soluble Ru­[(H2O)6]3+·3BF4 –, Ru­[(H2O)]6 3+–NaY, and Ru­[(H2O)6 3+]–MOF are similar, measured at initial reaction times when degradation is still not significant (Figure S14), and that product formation is maintained longer for the MOF catalyst. These results confirm that the catalytic activity is intrinsic to [Ru­(H2O)6]3 and that it is maintained for longer on solids that stabilize better the catalyst. Notice that a related catalyst, Ru­(OH)3–Al2O3, prepared in highly alkaline solutions and very active for dehydrogenations of alcohols, is merely inactive here since amine condensation is hampered under strongly basic conditions.
elements.clean_text: The [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF catalyst gives 90% isolated yield of imine 3 (entry 21 in ), the highest among all Ru catalysts tested. Hot-filtration experiments and ICP analysis show that Ru remains on the MOF after reaction, and XPS confirms the stability of the Ru catalyst within the MOF (Figures S6-S7). Kinetic experiments show that the initial turnover frequencies TOF0 for soluble Ru[(H2O)6]3+⋅3BF4 -, Ru[(H2O)]6 3+-NaY, and Ru[(H2O)6 3+]-MOF are similar, measured at initial reaction times when degradation is still not significant (Figure S14), and that product formation is maintained longer for the MOF catalyst. These results confirm that the catalytic activity is intrinsic to [Ru(H2O)6]3 and that it is maintained for longer on solids that stabilize better the catalyst. Notice that a related catalyst, Ru(OH)3-Al2O3, prepared in highly alkaline solutions and very active for dehydrogenations of alcohols, is merely inactive here since amine condensation is hampered under strongly basic conditions.

elements.content: shows that Ru­[(H2O)6]3+–NaY, −KY and −MOF catalyze the imination of primary benzyl and allyl alcohols with different amines in good isolated yields and selectivity under aerobic conditions, tolerating halogen (imines 4, 6, 14, 16, 20–21, 25–26), cyano (5), alkene (7, 16–17, 20, and 24), nitro (8 and 22–23), thioether (9 and 17), ester (10), trifluoromethane (11 and 21), heteroaromatic (12–13 and 31), alkyne (14–15), phenol (18–19), ether (19, 24, and 26), sulfonamide (22), boronic ester (25), and enamine (27–30) functionalities in the molecule. For alkyl enamines, cyclization occurs to give the corresponding Doebner–Miller quinoline products 32–33, which reflects the acidity imparted by the Ru3+ aqueous cation. A sample of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–NaY stored for 15 years on the bench shows the same catalytic activity as a fresh sample, and the same occurs for [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF stored for 1 year. These results illustrate the robustness of the supported [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ catalysts. Notice that flammability limits in industry for organic compounds generally restrict O2 concentration below 20%; thus, the results here presented are of interest not only for imine synthesis in the laboratory but also for a plausible industrial scale production.
elements.clean_text: shows that Ru[(H2O)6]3+-NaY, -KY and -MOF catalyze the imination of primary benzyl and allyl alcohols with different amines in good isolated yields and selectivity under aerobic conditions, tolerating halogen (imines 4, 6, 14, 16, 20-21, 25-26), cyano (5), alkene (7, 16-17, 20, and 24), nitro (8 and 22-23), thioether (9 and 17), ester (10), trifluoromethane (11 and 21), heteroaromatic (12-13 and 31), alkyne (14-15), phenol (18-19), ether (19, 24, and 26), sulfonamide (22), boronic ester (25), and enamine (27-30) functionalities in the molecule. For alkyl enamines, cyclization occurs to give the corresponding Doebner-Miller quinoline products 32-33, which reflects the acidity imparted by the Ru3+ aqueous cation. A sample of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-NaY stored for 15 years on the bench shows the same catalytic activity as a fresh sample, and the same occurs for [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF stored for 1 year. These results illustrate the robustness of the supported [Ru(H2O)6]3+ catalysts. Notice that flammability limits in industry for organic compounds generally restrict O2 concentration below 20%; thus, the results here presented are of interest not only for imine synthesis in the laboratory but also for a plausible industrial scale production.

elements.content: Scope for the imination of primary alcohols with amines using either Ru­[(H2O)6]3+–NaY, −KY, or −MOF as a catalyst. Imines 6, 7, and 9–10 were catalyzed by the MOF; imines 11–13 by KY, and the rest by NaY. The same yield of imine 4 is obtained with a 15-year old NaY catalyst, and the same occurs with imine 6 and the 1-year-old MOF. Two equivalents of O2 correspond to the air in the vial.
elements.clean_text: 2  Scope for the imination of primary alcohols with amines using either Ru[(H2O)6]3+-NaY, -KY, or -MOF as a catalyst. Imines 6, 7, and 9-10 were catalyzed by the MOF; imines 11-13 by KY, and the rest by NaY. The same yield of imine 4 is obtained with a 15-year old NaY catalyst, and the same occurs with imine 6 and the  1-year-old MOF. Two equivalents of O2 correspond to the air in the vial.

elements.content: The imination reaction shown in does not proceed in complete absence of O2, and H2 is not detected in the reaction atmosphere, even at [O2] ≪ air. If 1-dodecene and Pd/C (5 wt %) are added from the beginning to a reaction under optimized conditions (>80% of 3), no alkene hydrogenation occurs. These results discard acceptorless mechanisms and support a very efficient Ru-hydride quenching by O2 during reaction. The corresponding kinetic equation, according to kinetic results at initial times, is v 0 = k app[1]­[O2]­[Ru] at [O2] < air, and simply v 0 = ḱapp[1]­[Ru] at higher [O2] (Figure S15), which reflects a rapid saturation of the catalytic site for [O2] > air and that amine 2 does not participate in the rate-determining step (r.d.s.) of the reaction. In accordance, the dehydrogenation initial rate of 1, without adding amine 2, is very similar to the imination initial rate when 2 is present, and a kinetic isotopic effect (KIE) = 2.8 is obtained when α,α-deuterated benzyl alcohol (PhCD2OH) is used, regardless if amine 2 is present or not. These results strongly support that alcohol dehydrogenation is the rate-limiting step of the imination and that amine condensation and Ru–hydride capture by O2, to form water, are much faster processes.
elements.clean_text: The imination reaction shown in  does not proceed in complete absence of O2, and H2 is not detected in the reaction atmosphere, even at [O2] ≪ air. If 1-dodecene and Pd/C (5 wt %) are added from the beginning to a reaction under optimized conditions (>80% of 3), no alkene hydrogenation occurs. These results discard acceptorless mechanisms and support a very efficient Ru-hydride quenching by O2 during reaction. The corresponding kinetic equation, according to kinetic results at initial times, is v 0 = k app[1][O2][Ru] at [O2] < air, and simply v 0 = ḱapp[1][Ru] at higher [O2] (Figure S15), which reflects a rapid saturation of the catalytic site for [O2] > air and that amine 2 does not participate in the rate-determining step (r.d.s.) of the reaction. In accordance, the dehydrogenation initial rate of 1, without adding amine 2, is very similar to the imination initial rate when 2 is present, and a kinetic isotopic effect (KIE) = 2.8 is obtained when α,α-deuterated benzyl alcohol (PhCD2OH) is used, regardless if amine 2 is present or not. These results strongly support that alcohol dehydrogenation is the rate-limiting step of the imination and that amine condensation and Ru-hydride capture by O2, to form water, are much faster processes.

elements.content: A possible general mechanism for the Ru­[(H2O)6]3+ imination reaction, either supported or not, is shown in . Notice that the confining solids maximize the synthesis and lifetime of the Ru­[(H2O)6]3+ species but do not have a direct role in the reaction mechanism. The bigger pore size of the MOF with respect to the zeolite can explain the better catalytic activity of the former (>20% yield increase for product 3); however, the porosity of both solids is enough for reactants/products diffusion and does not hamper the reaction outcome.
elements.clean_text: A possible general mechanism for the Ru[(H2O)6]3+ imination reaction, either supported or not, is shown in . Notice that the confining solids maximize the synthesis and lifetime of the Ru[(H2O)6]3+ species but do not have a direct role in the reaction mechanism. The bigger pore size of the MOF with respect to the zeolite can explain the better catalytic activity of the former (>20% yield increase for product 3); however, the porosity of both solids is enough for reactants/products diffusion and does not hamper the reaction outcome.

elements.content: Mechanism of the [Ru­(H2O)6]3+-catalyzed imination of primary alcohols with amines.
elements.clean_text: 3  Mechanism of the [Ru(H2O)6]3+-catalyzed imination of primary alcohols with amines.

elements.content: The proposed mechanism involves that the alcohol displaces one water ligand on Ru3+ to trigger a beta-hydrogen elimination and that the intermediate Ru–H species is rapidly quenched by O2. The so-formed aldehyde condensates with the amine under acid catalysis to give the final imine product.
elements.clean_text: The proposed mechanism involves that the alcohol displaces one water ligand on Ru3+ to trigger a beta-hydrogen elimination and that the intermediate Ru-H species is rapidly quenched by O2. The so-formed aldehyde condensates with the amine under acid catalysis to give the final imine product.

elements.content: In summary, the imination of primary alcohols catalyzed by [Ru­(H2O)6]3+ supported on structured porous solids occurs in high yields and with a wide functional group tolerance under aerobic conditions, which is a step forward for imine synthesis. This work constitutes an example of cross-fertilization between zeolites and MOFs to support catallytically active metal species.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the imination of primary alcohols catalyzed by [Ru(H2O)6]3+ supported on structured porous solids occurs in high yields and with a wide functional group tolerance under aerobic conditions, which is a step forward for imine synthesis. This work constitutes an example of cross-fertilization between zeolites and MOFs to support catallytically active metal species.

cln_elements.content:
Results for the Imination of 4-Vinylbenzyl Alcohol (<bold>1</bold>) and 3,4-Dimethylaniline (<bold>2</bold>) with Ru Catalysts Entry Ru catalyst Yield of 3 (%) 1 RuCl3 0 2 Ru(acac)3 0 3 RuCl2(PPh)3 0 4 RuCl2(NH3)6 0 5 RuCl2(p-cymene) 0 6 Complex A 0 7 Complex B 0 8 Complex C 5 9 Complex D 0 10 Complex E 0 11 Ru (5 wt %)–C 0 12 Ru–Al2O3 0 13 TPAP 36 14 RuO2 14 15 Ru[(H2O)6]·3BF4 21 (18) 16 Ru(H2O)6–Al2O3 (0.1 wt % Ru) 27 17 Ru(H2O)6–SiO2 (0.1 wt % Ru) 26 18 Ru(H2O)6–TiO2 (0.1 wt % Ru) 23 19 Ru(H2O)6–MgO (0.1 wt % Ru) 20 20 Ru[(H2O)6]3+–NaY (1 wt % Ru) 73 (65) 21 [RuH2O)6]3+–MOF (∼3 wt % Ru) 97 (90) 22 Ru(OH)3– Al2O3 (1 wt % Ru) 7

2 equiv of O2 corresponds to the air in the vial. GC yields. Between parentheses, isolated yields.

Hydrogenated imine as only product found.

63% isolated yield in 2 g-scale; 58% after 5 uses. A 3 wt % sample gives 56% isolated yield.

Bare zeolites and MOF do not give any product. TBAP = Tetrapropylammonium perruthenate.

Table 1. Results for the Imination of 4-Vinylbenzyl Alcohol (1) and 3,4-Dimethylaniline (2) with Ru Catalysts

| Entry | Ru catalyst | Yield of 3 (%)[^a] |
|-------|-------------|-------------------|
| 1     | RuCl₃       | 0                 |
| 2     | Ru(acac)₃   | 0                 |
| 3     | RuCl₂(PPh)₃ | 0                 |
| 4     | RuCl₂(NH₃)₆ | 0                 |
| 5     | RuCl₂(p-cymene) | 0             |
| 6[^b] | Complex A   | 0                 |
| 7     | Complex B   | 0                 |
| 8     | Complex C   | 5                 |
| 9     | Complex D   | 0                 |
| 10    | Complex E   | 0                 |
| 11    | Ru (5 wt %)–C | 0                |
| 12    | Ru–Al₂O₃    | 0                 |
| 13    | TPAP        | 36                |
| 14    | RuO₂       | 14                |
| 15    | Ru[(H₂O)₆]·3BF₄ | 21 (18)        |
| 16    | Ru(H₂O)₆–Al₂O₃ (0.1 wt % Ru) | 27 |
| 17    | Ru(H₂O)₆–SiO₂ (0.1 wt % Ru) | 26 |
| 18    | Ru(H₂O)₆–TiO₂ (0.1 wt % Ru) | 23 |
| 19    | Ru(H₂O)₆–MgO (0.1 wt % Ru) | 20 |
| 20[^c] | Ru[(H₂O)₆]³⁺–NaY (1 wt % Ru) | 73 (65) |
| 21[^d] | [RuH₂O)₆]³⁺–MOF (∼3 wt % Ru) | 97 (90) |
| 22    | Ru(OH)₃–Al₂O₃ (1 wt % Ru) | 7     |

[^a]: 2 equiv of O₂ corresponds to the air in the vial. GC yields. Between parentheses, isolated yields.
[^b]: Hydrogenated imine as only product found.
[^c]: 63% isolated yield in 2 g-scale; 58% after 5 uses. A 3 wt % sample gives 56% isolated yield.
[^d]: Bare zeolites and MOF do not give any product. TBAP = Tetrapropylammonium perruthenate.

cln_elements.content: Views of the porous crystal structures, determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF in the ab (a) and bc (b) planes, respectively. (c) Perspective view of one single channel of [Ru­(H2O)6]3+–MOF along the c (left) axis. (d) Perspective view of a fragment of a single channel emphasizing the hydrogen bonds interactions. Cu­(II) and Ni­(II) cations from the coordination network are represented by cyan and blue polyhedra, respectively, whereas the ligands are depicted as gray sticks. Ru­(III) cations and water molecules hosted in the channels are represented by gold and red spheres with surface, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Views of the porous crystal structures, determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF in the ab (a) and bc (b) planes, respectively. (c) Perspective view of one single channel of [Ru(H2O)6]3+-MOF along the c (left) axis. (d) Perspective view of a fragment of a single channel emphasizing the hydrogen bonds interactions. Cu(II) and Ni(II) cations from the coordination network are represented by cyan and blue polyhedra, respectively, whereas the ligands are depicted as gray sticks. Ru(III) cations and water molecules hosted in the channels are represented by gold and red spheres with surface, respectively.

cln_elements.content: Scope for the imination of primary alcohols with amines using either Ru­[(H2O)6]3+–NaY, −KY, or −MOF as a catalyst. Imines 6, 7, and 9–10 were catalyzed by the MOF; imines 11–13 by KY, and the rest by NaY. The same yield of imine 4 is obtained with a 15-year old NaY catalyst, and the same occurs with imine 6 and the 1-year-old MOF. Two equivalents of O2 correspond to the air in the vial.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Scope for the imination of primary alcohols with amines using either Ru[(H2O)6]3+-NaY, -KY, or -MOF as a catalyst. Imines 6, 7, and 9-10 were catalyzed by the MOF; imines 11-13 by KY, and the rest by NaY. The same yield of imine 4 is obtained with a 15-year old NaY catalyst, and the same occurs with imine 6 and the  1-year-old MOF. Two equivalents of O2 correspond to the air in the vial.

metadata.title:
Stabilized Ru[(H2O)6]3+ in Confined Spaces (MOFs and Zeolites) Catalyzes the Imination of
Primary Alcohols under Atmospheric Conditions with Wide Scope
